At one point in your life, you probably thought, ‘I’m going to buy a nice T-shirt, but which one should I get?’ Luckily, the internet recommended about 15 of the best T-shirts for men, and today, we’re going over those 15, and we’re going to be ranking them. Well, I’m going to give them superlatives because it’s hard to say what’s best and worst, depending on who you are. But don’t worry, I’ve included the t-shirt from Merz. B that the internet has been slobber-gobbling all over for the past 3 years, worn by Jeremy Allen White in ‘The Bear.’ I have not seen it yet, although I’m assured there are no bears in it. Then we go to stuff that’s way lower priced, and to be honest, these two T-shirts from Uniqlo almost kill this review because they are so good, and they don’t cost a lot of money compared to others on the list. That being said though, there is one t-shirt that you have all recommended I buy for 3 years, and I ignored all of you. But I finally bought it – holy! So good! By the way, four of these shirts were given to me for free, and I’m not going to include them in the rankings because I want to make sure you know I paid for everything I’m talking about. Ranking The Best Men’s T-Shirts With High School Superlatives Okay, originally, I brutally ranked everything, one being the best, 11th being the worst, but then I looked at what I rated the worst and was like, ‘Well, some people might like that shirt and not think it’s the worst,’ so I don’t want them to go by that list. So I did the next best thing – High School superlatives. This excludes things that I got for free or that were lent to me. Think, if you went to a diner and you’re expecting a cheeseburger to cost $10, and it cost $1, you’d probably think, ‘How on Earth are you making this for $1?’ Everybody tells me that I should get these shirts and wear no other t-shirt, so I wanted to grab one.  This is the Kirkland six-pack that goes for $25, and it’s quite long – obviously, you always have to tuck it in. But for $4.20, this is freaking… it’s a fantastic T-shirt. It’s incredibly soft. I like the fit. It’s not too tight on the sleeves.  This collar is kind of constructed with a tiny bit of overlap (not bound). There’s very little sewing going on here. I like collars that are constructed with more of an overlap (bound) ’cause they’re tough, durable, they don’t wiggle and bend and stuff like that.  This is cheaper, it saves money, but still has a good look, and a nice tight neckline. Honestly, if you’re looking for a shirt under $5-$6, I can’t recommend this t-shirt enough. I wouldn’t be able to tell the difference.  This is Uniqlo. I really like the fit. I see what Tim Dessaint’s always saying, like this is great, and to be honest, if you’re looking to get a heavyweight kind of coarse feeling T-shirt with a bound collar with ribbing, which is what I like, I highly recommend this. If you’re looking for the best bargain t-shirt, this may be it. Uniqlo Supima Cotton T-shirt Price: $ | Weight: Not listed | Size tested: S | Feel: Soft, silky, durable, Premium feel | Shrink Test: 2.5% in width, 2% in length Supima cotton is extra-long staple cotton fiber. Some cotton fibers are half an inch long, others are an inch long. The benefit of being longer is it makes the t-shirt soft, silky, durable – it just feels really, really nice, and very premium.  The only thing about this shirt is the collar does sag. It’s not a bound collar, no ribbing or anything like that, so that kind of sucks, but if you want a Supima t-shirt for under 30 bucks, this is one of the best shirts that you can get. Premium Japanese Brands Hinoya Whitesville Price: $$ | Weight: 7oz | Size tested: S | Fit: Vintage tight fit (underwear style) | Feel: Very soft | Collar: Binding tape to prevent stretching | Shrink Test: 5.4% in width, 3% in length This is the jacked Instagram model special – this is the Whitesville t-shirt. It’s from a Japanese company that’s riffing on Old Americana underwear, so this shirt is cut like vintage t-shirts were, which is meant to be worn like underwear, so it’s very tight so as to not get in the way of you putting another shirt over it.  All in all, I’d really recommend it. This is by far one of the softest t-shirts on the list, feels great. For the price, I wouldn’t say it’s worth it until you look at this collar. This collar is interesting because it doesn’t use the bound type of construction, but they have binding tape over the collar that allows it not stretch a lot over time, so it holds its shape a little bit better. They went out of business, a Japanese company bought them and basically said, ‘make it again!’ and that’s what we have here. The tough part about this shirt is it’s made how things used to be made in the ’40s, and we have 84 years of different t-shirts since then, so some things seem a little weird. It feels like an underwear shirt, like Fruit of the Loom or Hanes. It feels like in that category, but it’s much more expensive. It’s an interesting choice to make a t-shirt that costs this much built this way, but it does have that old viby aesthetic look. But this knit, they call it compact, it’s so compact that it literally doesn’t feel like a knit product. It feels like you’re running your hands down glass. This is an unbelievably cool shirt. So good! I picked this one out specifically because of its blend – this is partially hemp. Hemp, I think in the next 10 years, is going to be in most clothing in all applications, and I don’t think it’s ever going to stop because it’s super eco-friendly, grows super fast, it’s much stronger than cotton, it has properties, cooling properties like linen.  I wish that the collar material was ribbing and not the same material as the shirt just because it doesn’t stretch over your head as easily. It wrinkles a little bit easier. It’s going to hold up for a very, very long time. I don’t mind it. I just wish it was ribbing. Medium-weight T-shirt, we have a blind stitch hem on the shoulders which is nice. Either way, you can’t go wrong with a graphic T-shirt from Dehen. This A New Medium brand, and in general, it is understated. It’s loop-wheeled, so it’s made very slowly. It has some nice subtle texture to it. It’s very plush and soft but feels heavy, fits great.  And it’s my friend Josh’s in-house clothing brand for Iron Shop Provisions. I got this shirt for free, so I can’t put it in the ranking, but it really is like a fantastic quality t-shirt. This might be the most affordable loopwheel t-shirt out there. I would recommend this t-shirt for that guy who wears 20 lb boots on each foot, has a giant leather wallet with a good art Hollywood chain that’s like going around it. That’s the kind of guy that would like this shirt because their fabric is… it’s like the opposite of Asket.  Still very dense, but it’s not silky smooth. It has a little coarse texture to it. I really like this shirt. Merz B. This is a size small. I got the funky mesh fabric just because I wanted to try something new because I have a – well, I had a Lady White T-shirt, I gave it to a friend or got stolen in Portugal. This is one of the greatest t-shirt brands of all time, hands down one of the greatest knitwear brands, I’d say. Wonder Looper Wonder Looper – made by one of my greatest friends in this industry, Bahzad and his wife Risa, nicest people in the absolute world. You probably know them from Naked and Famous. Fox Fiber Special Edition Price: $$$$ | Weight: 6.7oz | Size tested: S | Cotton Type: Fox Fiber | Properties: Organic cotton, All-natural, Pesticide-free, Fire-resistant, Disease-resistant | Shrink Test: 7.69% in width, 6% in length Before we get into Wonder Looper, this is one of my favorite cotton in the world, it is called Fox Fiber. Fox Fiber is a naturally colored cotton, so this isn’t dyed at all – organic cotton, all-natural, pesticide-free, fire-resistant (when it’s being grown), disease-resistant, and the person behind it, Sally Fox, is a cotton pioneer. She’s a legend in the cotton world because colored cotton was such a short-staple cotton that it was very difficult to spin it into yarns and make it into t-shirts. She changed that. She made it so it’s not a long-staple cotton, it’s not medium, it’s still short, but now you can make it into shirts and fibers and wovens, which is what we’re doing together. Case in point is this – the triple heavyweight t-shirt. This is the heaviest T-shirt. If you haven’t gotten into the world of heavyweight knits, this is far heavier than a Champion reverse weave. This is 69% heavier. It is an absolute tank. You could hear the sounds when I scratch it. If you want an indestructible T-shirt, you get this one. Tendrel Velva Sheen

Price: $$ | Weight: Not listed | Size tested: M | Feel: Similar to Fruit of the Loom and Hanes | Price: More expensive | Construction: Made like t-shirts from the 1940s | Aesthetic: Old, viby aesthetic | Shrink Test: 2.3% shrinkage in width, 0% in length

Velva Sheen – same idea as Whitesville, but very different execution. 

Whitesville: very soft, fluffy, kind of has a plush feeling, the sleeves are a little bit longer. 

Velva Sheen is doing the same thing; in fact, they’re more authentic. 

Whitesville is technically kind of referencing Velva Sheen because Velva Sheen was a company in, I think, Cincinnati in the 1930s. They went out of business, a Japanese company bought them and basically said, ‘make it again!’ and that’s what we have here.

The tough part about this shirt is it’s made how things used to be made in the ’40s, and we have 84 years of different t-shirts since then, so some things seem a little weird. It feels like an underwear shirt, like Fruit of the Loom or Hanes. It feels like in that category, but it’s much more expensive. It’s an interesting choice to make a t-shirt that costs this much built this way, but it does have that old viby aesthetic look.

Before we get into Wonder Looper, this is one of my favorite cotton in the world, it is called Fox Fiber. Fox Fiber is a naturally colored cotton, so this isn’t dyed at all – organic cotton, all-natural, pesticide-free, fire-resistant (when it’s being grown), disease-resistant, and the person behind it, Sally Fox, is a cotton pioneer.

She’s a legend in the cotton world because colored cotton was such a short-staple cotton that it was very difficult to spin it into yarns and make it into t-shirts. She changed that. She made it so it’s not a long-staple cotton, it’s not medium, it’s still short, but now you can make it into shirts and fibers and wovens, which is what we’re doing together.
